ceterms:description: The Physician Assistant program is a 27 month curriculum conferring a Master of Science in Physician Assistant Practice. First cohort begins June 2017.

ceterms:industryType.ceterms:targetNodeDescription: Offices of Physicians, Mental Health Specialists
ceterms:industryType.ceterms:targetNodeName: Offices of Physicians, Mental Health Specialists

ceterms:name: TESTING_Masters of Science in Physician Assistant Program

ceterms:occupationType.ceterms:targetNodeDescription: All physicians and surgeons not listed separately.
Diagnose and treat diseases using radioactive materials and techniques. May monitor radionuclide preparation, administration, and disposition.
Diagnose and treat disorders requiring physiotherapy to provide physical, mental, and occupational rehabilitation.

Apply knowledge of general preventive medicine and public health issues to promote health care to groups or individuals, and aid in the prevention or reduction of risk of disease, injury, disability, or death. May practice population-based medicine or diagnose and treat patients in the context of clinical health promotion and disease prevention.
Diagnose, treat, and help prevent injuries that occur during sporting events, athletic training, and physical activities.

Provide healthcare services typically performed by a physician, under the supervision of a physician. Conduct complete physicals, provide treatment, and counsel patients. May, in some cases, prescribe medication. Must graduate from an accredited educational program for physician assistants.

Diagnose, treat, and help prevent diseases using a system of practice that is based on the natural healing capacity of individuals. May use physiological, psychological or mechanical methods. May also use natural medicines, prescription or legend drugs, foods, herbs, or other natural remedies.

ceterms:ownedBy.ceterms:description: Since 1891, the University of La Verne has been dedicated to the belief that a quality, values-based education enriches the human condition by engendering service, scholarly accomplishment, and professionalism. Though decades of growth have changed its appearance and reach, La Verne has retained its sense of purpose, seeking to provide students with individual attention to spark personal growth through intellectual challenge and development. The University takes pride in knowing its nearly 50,000 alumni worldwide have made a difference in their professions and communities.
ceterms:ownedBy.ceterms:name: TESTING_University of La Verne

ceterms:requires.ceterms:experience:
Admission requirements will be consistent with the admission requirements of other professional health graduate programs. Admissions will be selective and enrollment will be limited. Due to the inherent demands of a graduate health care professional program, applicants should have a combination of a strong academic background and a high level of maturity and integrity. The criteria for admission will be based on a complete assessment of both academic and non-cognitive attributes. The application for admission and the applicants file must be complete before it is reviewed by the admission committee. Admission criteria are subject to change as the program develops. 
To be eligible for admissions the student must meet the following criteria for entry into the program: 
•	Completion of a bachelor’s degree from a regionally accredited university or college completed prior to entry into the program. 
•	Successful completion of all prerequisite coursework. 
•	Cumulative Natural Science pre-requisite GPA minimum 3.0 on a 4.0 scale. 
•	Overall Cumulative undergraduate GPA minimum 3.0 on a 4.0 scale. 
•	Repeated courses will be averaged in when calculating the GPA. 
•	Meet the Technical standards which are the abilities and skill that a student must possess in order to complete the program and are essential for clinical practice as a licensed PA. The technical standards involve skills in observation, communication, motor, intellectual, conceptual, integrative and quantitative; and behavioral/social. Please check the website for a detailed description of the technical standards. 
•	Two letters of recommendation assessing the applicant’s ability to be a physician assistant. One must be from a practicing MD/DO/PA. Letters must not be older than 1 year old prior to the application deadline. One letter may be from a college professor or supervisor. 
•	Sixteen (16) hours minimum of shadowing hours completed and documented by a licensed and practicing physician assistant. Shadowing hours are to be arranged by the applicant. The ULVPA program or faculty will not arrange nor recommend shadowing sites. 
•	Personal statement: 500-750 words, 12 Font, Times New Roman describing your personal goals in becoming a physician assistant. 
•	A panel interview: After initial assessment and screening of applications, a portion of selected applicants will be invited to interview on the University of La Verne Campus. 
•	Successful completion of Background Check
